subject: 2003 European TEX Conference paper discussing Quikskript

messageBody:
Recently received proceedings of EuroTEX 2003 conference. (TEX
referring to the scientific document typesetting system, and the
participants were members of a User Group of that system) An article
on fonts for artificial & synthetic alphabets caught my attention.
Unfortunately, I can't read very much of it, since it is written in
French. The English abstract says most font classifications don't
handle synthetic alphabets for a handful of different reasons, but
font designers shouldn't dismiss them as insignificant, because
contemporary writing forms continue to evolve, and the situation may
change. Both Quikscript and the earlier Shavian alphabet are
discussed in some fashion.

There seems to be considerable discussion of some alphabets that were
designed to reform spelling or other aspects of written language, and
a section on, maybe, *novelty* alphabets (e.g., pictographs, Standard
Galactic, and a writing system attributed to Christian-Marc Schmidt,
Parsons School of Design, Greenwich Village NY, in which the 26
English letters are arranged around a circle like an analog clock
face and you write a word by drawing segments that connect the
successive letters.

REFERENCE

Tombeur, Jef; Réformes philanthropiques et réformes
orthotypographiques, alphabets artificiels et synthétiques.
TUGboat 24 (2003): 605-618.

[The same author has another article on "Teacher Fonts" that are used
to teach handwriting improvement (penmanship). This seems to be all
about "standard" alphabets, although it evokes one of the rationales
of Quikskript, "help[ing] students acquire a fluid and quick
handwriting for note-taking".]
